record_data.record_plain_text:
BYLAWS OF THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP
Article 1
Purposes
The members of the Rocky Mountain Reserve Group (RMRG) believe that the maintenance of reserves, the sharing of reserve responsibilities and the coordination of reserve activation will yield important benefits to their respective customers within Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, Utah, Wyoming and other adjoining areas. Specifically, through the sharing of reserve responsibilities: The members' electric systems can be supplied and protected during emergencies with less aggregate operating reserve capability and with a consequent net savings in expenses; Emergency conditions can be met with less likelihood of curtailment or impairment of electric service to customers; and, The parties can promote, facilitate and coordinate planning and development of their respective electric systems to the benefit of the interconnected system. To these ends the members are willing to obligate themselves to maintain defined levels of reserves, coordinate reserve sharing and activation, and will reserve transmission capacity for such purposes.
Article 2
Members
Section 1. Membership. Membership in the corporation shall be open to entities eligible to file an action under Section 211 of the Federal Power Act.
Section 2. Membership Classes. The corporation shall have two classes of members. One class shall be designated as full members and is composed of entities which 1) own generation resources or have sufficient contractual rights or operational control of generation resources in order to effectively deliver the reserve obligations established per the Rocky Mountain Reserve Group policies to a substation of a RMRG member as approved by the Operations Committee and 2) which otherwise meet the qualifications for membership. The second member class shall be designated as affiliate members. Affiliate members may be any entity, otherwise qualified for membership, which does not meet the criteria for full member status.
Section 3. Membership Contribution. Each class of member shall have a membership contribution obligation which amount must be submitted in full along with the membership application. The amount of the membership contribution for each class shall be established by the board of directors. Prior to January 1, 1999, there will be no membership contribution required. After that date the membership contribution will be set in an amount which recognizes the prior capital contribution of the members.
Section 4. Application for Membership. Any entity that desires to join the Reserve Sharing Group shall send a letter requesting membership with 1) a check for the full amount of the membership contribution and 2) a check to cover the costs of application processing. The application may require the submission of documents sufficient to assure the corporation that the new member can effectively meet its obligations.
Section 5. New Members. New members meeting the membership requirements will be admitted to the corporation by the board of directors. Upon admission, the corporation will deposit the membership contribution into the corporate account. If admission is denied the check for membership contribution will be returned to the applicant. Each new member is responsible for providing to the corporate secretary a designation of the member representative and an alternate representative. When new members are added, the budget, assessments, voting strengths and reserve responsibility ratios of the members shall be revised as appropriate.
Section 6. Member Withdrawal. A member may voluntarily withdraw from the corporation at any time upon two (2) years written notice. Upon withdrawal the member will remain liable for the assessments due and payable until the date of withdrawal. The membership contribution is nonrefundable. The board of directors may waive or reduce the notice period for withdrawal.
Section 7. Member Attendance. Any member may attend any meeting of the corporation, the board of directors, or any committee and, upon proper recognition by the chair, may participate in such meeting.
Section 8. Termination of Membership. The board of directors may terminate the membership of any member which, after written notice, a reasonable cure period and a hearing, 1) does not timely contribute its annual assessment, 2) no longer meets membership criteria, or 3) continues to violate the policies adopted and in effect. Termination shall not relieve the member from any past amounts owing to the corporation. Section 9. Suspension of reserve sharing functions - NWPP Should all members who are Balancing Area Authorities join the Northwest Power Pool, on the day and hour that all these members who are Balancing Area Authorities simultaneously begin reserve sharing operations as members of the Northwest Power Pool Reserve Sharing Group, the RMRG will discontinue operations as a reserve sharing group and all By-Law Sections and policies and all operating guides and procedures relating to on-going operations including maintaining, sharing, carrying and activating reserves are suspended. The day and hour for suspension will be determined by action of the board of directors. Until the RMRG is dissolved per procedures identified elsewhere in the By-Laws and in the Articles of Incorporation, the RMRG will continue to exist to complete remaining administrative tasks such as outstanding Activation settlements, Reportable Disturbance audits, financial audits, tax filings, and administrative cost settlements.
Article 3
Assessments and Billing
Section 1. Full Members. The amount of the yearly assessment for full members will be reviewed by the board of directors annually and submitted to a vote of the membership at the annual meeting.
Section 2. Affiliate Members. The amount of the yearly assessment for affiliate members will be reviewed by the board of directors annually and submitted to a vote of the membership at the annual meeting.
Section 3. Assessments. Annual assessments shall be sufficient to allow for payment of all ongoing operational and capital expenses of the corporation for the year in which the assessment is collected. At the discretion of the board of directors the assessments may be collected quarterly or monthly or alternately collected in the calendar year after which the expenses were incurred.
Section 4. Calculation of Assessments. The amount of the annual assessment for full members will be developed based upon the following formula: Thirty five percent (35%) of the annual capital and operational expenses will be recovered equally from the full members and sixty five percent (65%) will be recovered based upon the annual average reserve responsibility ratio of each member, excluding adjustments to the reserve responsibility ratio made for additional reserves carried due to transmission constraints. The board of directors may suggest modifications to this formula based upon unique circumstances, which suggestions will be submitted to a vote of the membership at the annual meeting. The assessment for affiliate members will be limited to that amount which the membership determines corresponds with the annual expenditures which directly benefit affiliate members divided equally among the number of affiliate members as of July 1 of each year.
Section 5. Billing and Payments. Payments for assessments, penalties or other amounts billed will be due on the twentieth (20th) day after receipt of the bill. Amounts not paid on or before the due date shall accrue interest at a rate of one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month.
Article 4
Meetings of Members
Section 1. Annual Meeting. The annual meeting of all members of the corporation shall be held each year on such date as may be fixed by the board of directors. The annual meeting shall be held for the election of directors, the establishment of the budget and membership assessments, and the transaction of such other proper business. At each such annual meeting, the board of directors shall submit to the membership a report of the corporation's business activities during the preceding year, the general financial condition of the corporation and recommendations concerning the budget and assessments for the upcoming year.
Section 2. Special Meetings. Special meetings of the members may be called by or at the direction of the president.
Section 3. Notice of Meetings. Notice of any meetings, annual or special, shall specify the time, place and purpose of the meeting and shall be delivered by mail to all members. Meetings may be held by conference call or other electronic medium. Notice for meetings shall normally be sent not less than 10 and no more than 30 days prior to the meeting. Notice by electronic message may supplement the mailed notice required by this section.
Section 4. Voting. All members present shall have voting privileges. All motions and resolutions shall be deemed adopted when approved by a two-thirds double majority vote of the members present meaning that the issue must be approved by two-thirds of the members present and must be approved by two-thirds of the voting strength of the full members represented. (See Policy E for voting sequence)
Section 5. Member Votes. Each full and affiliate member shall have one vote. In addition, for purposes of the weighted vote the population of full members shall have an additional 100 votes divided (fractionally when necessary) among the full members in accordance with each full member's annual average reserve responsibility ratio. The total votes apportioned to each full member as a result of this process will be that full member's voting strength. The annual average reserve responsibility ratio and each full member's voting share shall be calculated by the group administrator, subject to review by the Operations Committee, prior to the annual meeting based upon the reserve responsibilities ratios for the prior twelve (12) months.
Section 6. Action Without Meeting. Any action which might be taken at a meeting of the members may be taken without a meeting if a written consent setting forth the action to be taken is signed by all members entitled to vote.
Section 7. Quorum. A quorum for any meeting of the membership shall be the presence of two-thirds of the full members having, in aggregate, two-thirds of the voting strength.
Section 8. Attendance by Electronic Means. Any meeting of the members may be attended through electronic means, and any member so attending will be considered present. For members attending electronically, votes may be confirmed by telefax or other electronic means.
Article 5
Board of Directors
Section 1. Directors. The corporation shall have a board of directors consisting of a number of directors equal to the total of the full members, plus additional directors representing the affiliate member class in a ratio of one director for each five full members (rounded to the nearest integer divisible by five). Each full member shall appoint one director, which director may be removed by that full member. Directors representing the affiliate class shall be elected by the affiliate members. Directors shall not be required to be residents of Colorado to serve. Directors shall serve a term of one year and may be re-appointed or re-elected.
Section 2. Vacancies. Vacancies on the board of directors may be filled for the unexpired term. For the vacancy of a full member representative, a new director will be appointed by that full member. For the vacancy of an affiliate member, a new director will be selected from the affiliate class by a majority vote of the remaining directors at any meeting of the board of directors.
Section 3. Power and Duties of the Directors. The board of directors shall have control and general management of the affairs, property and business of the corporation and, subject to these bylaws, may adopt such rules and regulations for that purpose and for the conduct of its meetings. The powers of the board of directors shall include, but not be limited to:
* The appointment and removal of the officers of the corporation. * Approval and amendment of bylaws. * Development of annual budget and assessment recommendations. * Formation of, and appointment of members to, any ad hoc committees. * Review of policies recommended or adopted by committees. * Review, upon request, of penalty assessments. * Establishment and maintenance of systems of accounts and records. * Approval and termination of members. * Hiring of a group administrator and the fixing of compensation. * Approval of contracts with a value in excess of $10,000.00.
Section 4. Election of Directors. The election of the directors representing the affiliate members shall be at the annual meeting of the membership. Voting may occur by acclamation, otherwise nominees receiving the greatest number of votes shall be elected. No member shall have more than one person from that organization serving on the board of directors.
Section 5. Chairperson of the Board. From among its members, the board of directors shall elect a chairperson of the board. The chairperson of the board shall preside at meetings of the board of directors. The chairperson shall also serve as president of the corporation.
Article 6
Meetings of Directors
Section 1. Annual Meeting. The annual meeting of the board of directors shall be held immediately after and at the same place where the annual meeting of the membership is held. The meeting will be held for the purpose of electing officers, appointing committees, establishing a schedule of regular meetings, and for the transaction of any other business as may properly come before the board of directors. No notice shall be required for the annual meeting of the board of directors.
Section 2. Special Meetings. Special meetings of the board of directors may be called by the chairperson of the board.
Section 3. Notice of Meetings. Except for the annual meeting of the board of directors, notice of the time and place of any meeting of the board of directors shall normally be sent to the directors and the membership not later than ten (10) days prior to the meeting. Such notice may be in writing or may be sent by electronic medium. An agenda outlining the business to be discussed and decided must be included with the notice, however the board of directors, upon two-thirds majority approval, may discuss and decide issues not listed on the agenda. Meetings of the board of directors shall be open to all members. Meetings of the board of directors may be held by conference call or other electronic medium. Meetings may be noticed sooner than ten (10) days, but such notices must be by electronic medium with a reliable indication of receipt.
Section 4. Voting. A quorum for any meeting of the board shall be the presence of two-thirds of the full member representatives having, in aggregate, two-thirds of the member voting strength. The act of a two-thirds double majority of the directors present shall be an act of the directors, meaning that the issue must be approved by two-thirds of the directors present and must be approved by two-thirds of the voting strength represented. (See Policy E for voting sequence)
Section 5. Action Without Meeting. Any action which might be taken at a meeting of the board of directors may be taken without a meeting if a written consent setting forth the action to be taken is signed by all of the directors entitled to vote.
Section 6. Attendance by Electronic Means. Any meeting of the board of directors may be attended through electronic means, and any director so attending will be considered present. For directors attending electronically, votes may be confirmed by telefax or other electronic means.
Article 7
Officers and Duties
Section 1. Officers. The officers of the corporation shall consist of a president, a vice president, a secretary and a treasurer. Any two or more offices may be held by the same person, except the offices of president and secretary. Officers shall be elected by the board of directors at the annual meeting of the directors or at any regular or special meeting called for that purpose.
Section 2. President. The president shall chair meetings of the members, and may have any other powers and duties as may be conferred by the board of directors. The president shall, subject to the direction and supervision of the board of directors, be the chief executive officer of the corporation and shall have general and active control of its affairs and business and general supervision of its officers, agents and employees. The president shall have the authority to sign all contracts and other instruments on behalf of the corporation, except as the authority may be restricted by resolutions of the board of directors adopted from time to time.
Section 3. Vice President. The vice president shall have the duties that the board of directors or the president may delegate from time to time. In the absence of the president, the duties and powers of the office shall be performed and exercised by the vice president. Section 4. Secretary. The secretary shall keep the minutes and act as secretary of all meetings of the members and of the board of directors. The secretary shall be the custodian of the corporation records. The secretary shall retain a record of all member representatives and alternates. The secretary shall perform all duties usually incident to the office of the secretary, those duties specified in these bylaws, and other duties that may from time to time be assigned by the board of directors.
Section 5. Treasurer. The treasurer shall have general supervision over the care and custody of the funds and securities of the corporation and shall deposit the same or cause the same to be deposited in the name of the corporation in the financial institution(s) that the board of directors may designate. The treasurer shall keep or cause to be kept full and accurate accounts of all receipts and disbursements of the corporation and whenever required by the board of directors, shall render or cause to be rendered financial statements of the corporation.
Article 8
Committees
Section 1. Ad Hoc Committees. The board of directors shall have the power and authority to create ad hoc committees and appoint members to such ad hoc committees at the annual meeting or at any regular meeting or special meeting of the board called for that purpose. Such ad hoc committee may include as a member, where appropriate, a director who will be responsible for liaison between the board and the ad hoc committee.
Section 2. Operations Committee (OC). There shall exist a permanent Operations Committee, which will be composed of a representative from each member. The chair of the Operations Committee shall be a Board Member or Alternate. The Operations Committee will meet as necessary to perform its delegated functions.
A notice and agenda outlining the business to be discussed and decided at any meeting of the Operations Committee shall normally be sent to all members prior to the meeting; however, the Operations Committee may discuss and decide issues not listed on the agenda if so authorized by a vote of the members. Such notice may be in writing or may be sent by electronic medium. Meetings may be held by conference call or other electronic medium. When requested, the group administrator shall serve as a nonvoting member and secretary for the Operations Committee.
The responsibilities of the Operations Committee shall include:
* Review, develop, modify and adopt the operational policies and guidelines. * Organize and distribute approved policies and guidelines. * Review and inform members concerning national and regional reliability standards. * Represent the corporation in national and regional reliability organizations. * Coordinate activities with other committees. * Other duties as assigned by the board of directors.
Each member of the Operations Committee will have one vote and additionally each full member shall cast the same number of weighted votes that member is authorized to cast at a meeting of the members. Issues presented to the Operations Committee will be adopted when approved by a two-thirds double majority vote of the members present meaning that the issue must be approved by two-thirds of the members present and must be approved by two-thirds of the voting strength of the full members represented. A quorum of the Operations Committee is present when two-thirds of the members are present provided that the members present also represent two-thirds of the voting strength. ( See Policy E for voting sequence )
Section 3. Attendance by Electronic Means. Any meeting of any committee may be attended through electronic means, and any member so attending will be considered present. For members attending electronically, votes may be confirmed by telefax or other electronic means.
Article 9
Policies
Section 1. Effect of Policies. The policies, as adopted by the Operations Committee and attached to these bylaws as exhibits, are binding upon all members of the corporation. All members agree to undertake their best efforts to conform their actions with the policies of the corporation. Members may be subject to penalties, due and payable to the corporation as contractual obligations, for violation of the policies.
Section 2. Publication of Policies. In order to be effective and binding upon the members, the policies of the corporation must be published as exhibits to these bylaws. Any new or amended policy must be distributed to the membership prior to its effectiveness. The policy must indicate on its face an effective date at which time it will be binding and enforceable upon all members, provided the policy has been sent by first class mail postage prepaid and by electronic medium with a reliable indication of receipt to all members at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date.
Section 3. Review by the Board of Directors. Every policy adopted or modified by the Operations Committee shall be immediately sent by the Operations Committee chair to all members of the board of directors by electronic means with a reliable indication of receipt. At any time prior to the effective date of the policy as adopted or modified, the board of directors may reject the policy, which rejection shall be immediately communicated to all members by first class mail, postage prepaid and by electronic medium with a reliable indication of receipt.
Section 4. Operating Guidelines. The Operations Committee may develop specific operation guidelines the purpose of which is to further clarify the policies. Any operation guidelines developed by the Operations Committee shall be published and distributed to the members in the same fashion provided for the distribution of policies.
Article 10
Group Administrator
Section 1. Group Administrator. At the discretion of the board of directors and in accordance with the annual budget approved by the membership, the corporation may employ a group administrator with responsibilities as defined and delegated by the board of directors. The board of directors shall be responsible for selection of the group administrator and for the establishment of compensation and other terms of employment, which shall be outlined in a written agreement between RMRG and the group administrator.
Section 2. Limitation of Liability of the group administrator. Any limitation of liability expressly granted by RMRG to the group administrator in their written agreement, shall also be recognized and effective between any member and the group administrator.
Section 3. Indemnification of the Group Administrator. Any indemnification of the group administrator by RMRG in their written agreement, shall also be recognized and effective between any member and the group administrator, provided however, that this Section 3 shall not apply to any member that is an agency of the United States Government to the extent that this Section 3 conflicts with applicable Federal law.
Article 11
Negotiable Instruments
Section 1. Signature on Checks. All checks, drafts, bills of exchange, notes or other obligations or orders for the payment of money shall be signed in the name of the corporation by the officers or persons that the board of directors of the corporation may from time to time designate by resolution.
Article 12
Amendments
Section 1. Amendment of Bylaws. The board of directors shall have the power to alter, amend or repeal the bylaws of the corporation at any annual meeting of the board of directors or at any regular meeting or special meeting called for that purpose.
Section 2. Amendment of the Articles of Incorporation. The articles of incorporation may be amended on resolution of the board of directors and subsequent approval of the members.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP
POLICY A DEFINITIONS
A-1. Reserved for future use
A-2. PURPOSE: The purpose of this Policy is to define certain terms used in the bylaws and Policies of the Rocky Mountain Reserve Group.
A-3. TERM: This Policy shall continue in effect unless and until modified or superseded as set forth in the bylaws.
A-4. DEFINITIONS: The following terms, when used herein, shall have the meanings specified unless and until modified: A-4.1 Activated Reserve means for any member or members the amount of Contingency Reserve activated or to be activated and delivered as Contingency Assistance as a result of a Reportable Disturbance, another Contingency of a Member, or as a result of a request for Emergency Assistance. A-4.2 Affiliate Member means an affiliate member as defined in the RMRG bylaws. A-4.3 Annual Peak Load means the maximum hourly Load for a member for the preceding twelve month period. A-4.4 Available Transmission Capacity (ATC) is the measure of transfer capability remaining in the physical transmission network for further commercial activity, over and above already-committed uses.
A-4.5 Contingency means the sudden loss of generation and/or Contingent Contract Capacity. A-4.6 Contingency Assistance means the delivery to a member or members of capacity and energy from activated reserves by one or more other members in response to a Reportable Disturbance or other Contingency of a member. A-4.7 Contingent Contract Capacity means capacity which is available contingent on the availability of one or more specific resources.
A-4.8 Contingency Reserve or Contingency Reserve Capacity means, as to any member for any period, the excess resources, which can be made effective within ten (10) minutes, maintained to respond to Contingencies and/or Emergencies and is equal to Operating Capacity minus Load, both as defined below. Contingency Reserves is the provision of capacity deployed by the members of the RMRG to meet a member's loss of resource, the Disturbance Control Standard (DCS) and other NERC and Regional Reliability Organization contingency requirements. A-4.9 Contingency Reserve Quota means the quantity of Contingency Reserve Capacity required of each member for any period.
A-4.10 Emergency means an operating circumstance where a shortage of generation resources poses an immediate threat to firm loads of one or more members of the Group or a third party and/or an event which necessitates the immediate activation of reserves.
A-4.11 Emergency Assistance means capacity and energy requested by and provided to a member or members by other members in response to an Emergency other than a Reportable Disturbance.
A-4.12 Firm Contract Capacity means that capacity which is available from a member or third party where the supplier provides the reserves.
A-4.13 Group means the RMRG acting as a reserve sharing group as defined by NERC and/or WECC.
A-4.14 Group Administrator means the member or other designee of the Group who performs the function of coordinating Group activities per contract.
A-4.15 Group Peak Load means the maximum coincident hourly Load of the members that occurs or is forecast to occur on a given day.
A-4.16 Largest Hazard means the number of megawatts associated with a member's largest single contingency loss of generation due to the loss of any single synchronized generating unit or single transmission circuit of the member's system, or the largest block of scheduled Contingent Contract Capacity which can be curtailed at one time. This amount may be reduced by subtracting the number of megawatts of power contracted for by another member or third party for a contract period of one year or greater which is contingent upon the operation of that generation or the receipt of that contract capacity. Additionally, if a member activates reserves for a generator or generators of a non-member, that member must add to its largest single contingency the largest single contingency of this non-member.
A-4.17 Load means, as to any member for any period, the amount of electric power for which that member is obligated to provide Contingency Reserve and it shall be the sum of the following: A-4.17.1 Power carried on a member's synchronized generating facilities, including those generating facilities owned by non-RMRG members for which the member desires to activate Contingency Reserves, plus A-4.17.2 Firm Contract Capacity of limited contractual term, as set by the Operations Committee, scheduled from another member or third party, plus A-4.17.3 Contingent Contract Capacity scheduled from another member or third party where the receiver is obligated to provide the reserves, plus A-4.17.4 Power scheduled from another member or third party where the receiver provides the reserves plus A-4.17.5 Inadvertent Energy received, plus A-4.17.6 Emergency Assistance and/or Contingency Assistance scheduled from another member, minus A-4.17.7 Contingent Contract Capacity scheduled to another member or third party where the receiver provides the reserves, minus A-4.17.8 Firm Contract Capacity of limited contractual term, as set by the Operations Committee, scheduled to another member or third party, minus A-4.17.9 Interruptible load meeting criteria set forth by the Operations Committee, minus A-4.17.10 Power scheduled to another member or third party where the receiver provides the reserves, minus A-4.17.11 Emergency Assistance and/or Contingency Assistance scheduled to another member, minus A-4.17.12 Inadvertent energy delivered
A-4.18 Member means a full member as defined in the RMRG bylaws.
A-4.19 NERC means the North American Electric Reliability Corporation, or its successor, which sets performance standards to ensure reliability of interconnected electric power systems in North America.
A-4.20 Operating Capacity means, as to any member for any period, the sum in net megawatts of the resources which are either loaded or that portion of the resource which can be loaded within ten (10) minutes inclusive of both transactions which are or can be scheduled within ten (10) minutes, the megawatts of Load which can be removed from the system within ten (10) minutes and capacity made available by an AC/DC/AC tie that meets the criteria set forth by the Operations Committee; including specifically: A-4.20.1 Available capacity of a member's generating facilities, plus A-4.20.2 Firm Contract Capacity of limited contractual term, as set by the Operations Committee, scheduled from another member or third party, plus A-4.20.3 Contingent Contract Capacity scheduled from a member or third party where the receiver provides the reserves, plus A-4.20.4 Firm Contract Capacity and/or Contingent Contract Capacity that is available per respective contract provisions, but not scheduled, from a member or third party, plus A-4.20.5 Firm or contingent Operating Reserve - Spinning available from a member or third party (spinning reserve purchase), plus A-4.20.6 Firm or contingent Operating Reserve - Supplemental available from a member or third party (non-spinning reserve purchase), plus A-4.20.7 Load which the member has the right, through contract or ownership, to remove or cause to be removed from the system within 10 minutes of the Contingency occurring, plus, A-4.20.8 Capacity lost as a result of a forced outage occurring within the current scheduling hour or within the most recent preceding scheduling hour for which operating reserves, normally reported per section(s) A-4.20.1 through A-4.20.7 were either lost and/or activated as a result of the forced outage, (credit operating capacity) minus A-4.20.9 Contingent Contract Capacity scheduled to a member or third party where the receiver provides the reserves, minus A-4.20.10 Firm Contract Capacity of limited contractual term, as set by the Operations Committee, scheduled to another member or third party, minus A-4.20-11 Firm Contract Capacity and/or Contingent Contract Capacity that is committed per respective contract provisions, but not scheduled, to a member or third party, minus A-4.20.12 Firm or contingent Operating Reserve - Spinning committed to a member or third party (spinning reserve sale), minus A-4.20.13 Firm or contingent Operating Reserve - Supplemental committed to a member or third party (non-spinning reserve sale).
A-4.21 Operating Reserve - Spinning means reserves that meet the definition of Operating Reserve-Spinning in the applicable NERC Glossary of Terms that also meets all WECC requirements related to spinning reserve.
A-4.22 Operating Reserve - Spinning Quota means the quantity of Operating Reserve - Spinning capacity required of each member for any period. A-4.23 Operating Reserve - Supplemental means reserves that meet the definition of Operating Reserve - Supplemental in the applicable NERC Glossary of Terms Used in NERC Reliability Standards.
A-4.24 Operations Committee Recognized Path means a transmission line, transformer, or group of transmission lines that the Operations Committee (OC) recognizes may be a constraint on Contingency Reserve deliveries between members and may require temporary additional reserves. A-4.25 Planning Window means the future calendar days for which the members are forecasting load and Operating Reserve Quotas.
A-4.26 Receipt Matrix means a table that shows for each respective member, the quantity in megawatts which the member lost for a given Activated Reserve event. A-4.27 Reportable Disturbance means a Contingency experienced by any RMRG member or members of sufficient magnitude to meet the definition of Reportable Disturbance in effect at the NERC and/or WECC.
A-4.28 Reserve Assistance means Contingency Reserve activated and/or maintained by member(s), in addition to their normal quotas, thereby enabling the Group to meet its aggregate obligations when other individual member(s) are deficient in maintaining their reserve obligations.
A-4.29 Response Matrix means a table that shows the Contingency Reserves with which each respective member must respond for various Reportable Disturbances.
A-4.30 Temporary Additional Reserves means an increase in the Contingency Reserve Quota for a member or members due to a temporary transmission constraint that restricts the delivery of Contingency Reserves from one or more members to one or more members.
A-4.31 Transmission Path Margin is the difference between the Operations Committee Recognized Path rating (System Operating Limit) and the sum of two flow components: the path's pre-contingency flow plus the incremental flow that analysis or experience indicates would result on the same path due to a Contingency activation. Lack of adequate Transmission Path Margin on an Operations Committee Recognized Path means that if the most impacting generation Contingency were to occur the actual flow on that path is predicted to exceed its respective System Operating Limit (SOL).
A-4.32 WECC means the Western Electricity Coordinating Council, a regional council of NERC, or its successor organization in which the RMRG operates. WECC is the Regional Entity ("RE") responsible for proposing Regional Reliability Standards and for enforcement of NERC's Reliability Standards, regional and continent-wide, against registered entities in the Western Interconnection. WECC also performs registered entity functions, including Interchange Authority and Reliability Coordinator ("RC").
POLICY B RESERVES AND RESERVE SHARING
ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP POLICY B RESERVES AND RESERVE SHARING INDEX
SECTION PAGE B-1. Reserved for future use B-1 B-2. PURPOSE B-1 B-3. TERM B-2 B-4. RMRG RESERVE SHARING PHILOSOPHY B-2 B-5. GROUP CONTINGENCY RESERVE CAPACITY B-2 B-6. GROUP OPERATING RESERVE - SPINNING CAPACITY B-4 B-7. GROUP OPERATING RESERVE - SUPPLEMENTAL CAPACITY B-4 B-8. RESERVE RESPONSIBILITY RATIO B-5 B-9. MEMBER CONTINGENCY RESERVE QUOTAS B-6 B-10. ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP
POLICY B RESERVES AND RESERVE SHARING B-1. Reserved for future use B-2. PURPOSE: Membership in the RMRG provides benefits to all members through the sharing of reserve requirements only when all members participate fully by both having available Contingency Reserves and being able to deliver and receive those reserves for any qualified resource loss within the reserve group. The purpose of this Policy is to define the aggregate reserve requirements of the Rocky Mountain Reserve Group (RMRG) and to specify the apportionment thereof among the members. The determination of the reserve obligations of the individual Members are described and conditions and procedures for activating reserves are established in this Policy. Reserve reporting and accounting requirements are defined as are penalties for deficiencies in carrying and activating reserves. It is the intent of RMRG to meet or exceed the applicable reserve and reserve sharing performance standards and reporting requirements of NERC and/or WECC, or successor organizations, as a reserve sharing group.
B-3. TERM: This Policy shall continue in effect unless and until modified or superseded as set forth in the bylaws.
B-4. RMRG RESERVE SHARING PHILOSOPHY The Contingency Reserve responsibility is intended to be shared among the members, is limited to those reserves which are held and activated as Contingency Assistance, provided that such reserve may also be activated in the form of Emergency Assistance. Reserve responsibilities of an individual member that are the result of its use of interruptible imports, necessary for the member to meet on-call demands of others, or the result of the member's load regulation requirements, shall be the sole responsibility of the member, except as established practices of the Group permit. Unless explicitly noted, references herein to Contingency Reserves and its Operating Reserve - Spinning and Operating Reserve - Supplemental components shall refer to that Operating Reserve intended for reserve sharing, exclusive of reserves required for other reserve obligations of the member.
B-5. GROUP CONTINGENCY RESERVE CAPACITY: B-5.1 It is the intent of the RMRG to meet or exceed the requirements of NERC and/or WECC for maintaining Contingency Reserve and for meeting the performance standards for Reportable Disturbances through activation of Contingency Reserves.
B-5.2 As a normal minimum, unless and until the Operations Committee shall establish different requirements, the aggregate amount of Contingency Reserve Capacity to be scheduled jointly for the combined electric systems of the members shall be the amount of Contingency Reserve required in the then-applicable WECC Regional Reliability Standard or NERC Reliability Standard, whichever is greater.
B-5.3 If a penalty is assessed against the Group for violation of any NERC and/or WECC requirements referred to in B-5.1 above, the penalty, whether monetary or in the form of an additional reserve requirement, will be assigned to the member or members responsible for the violation. If the violation is attributable to the error of more than one member, or group error, then the penalty will be allocated among all members that contributed to the violation on a pro-rata basis based on their RRR compared to the sum of RRRs for all contributing members.
B-5.4 After the occurrence of any event necessitating the use of Contingency Reserve Capacity, the then applicable Contingency Reserve requirement shall be restored by the members by the end of the Contingency Reserve Restoration Period as required by the NERC and/or WECC Reliability Standards unless and until the Operations Committee shall establish a different period of time, through the activation of replacement capacity.
B-6. GROUP OPERATING RESERVE - SPINNING CAPACITY: As a normal minimum, unless and until the Operations Committee shall establish different requirements, the aggregate Operating Reserve - Spinning component of Contingency Reserve Capacity for the combined electric system of the members shall be no less than one-half (1/2) the aggregate amount of the Contingency Reserve Capacity required pursuant to Section B-5.1. At no time may the Operations Committee reduce the amount of aggregate Operating Reserve - Spinning below the level of Operating Reserves - Spinning required for compliance with the NERC or WECC Reliability Standards.
B-7. GROUP OPERATING RESERVE - SUPPLEMENTAL CAPACITY: Operating Reserve - Supplemental capacity may be utilized to provide that portion of the aggregate Contingency Reserve Capacity of the members pursuant to Section B-5 provided that the Operating Reserve - Spinning requirement pursuant to Section B-6 is met. In general, Operating Reserve - Supplemental may include qualifying interruptible load, interruptible exports, off-line quick starting generation, etc.
B-8. RESERVE RESPONSIBILITY RATIO: As a normal procedure, unless and until the Operations Committee shall establish different requirements, the Reserve Responsibility Ratio (RRR) for each member of the Group shall be computed for each six month period starting April 1 and October 1. The Reserve Responsibility Ratio is equal to fifty percent (50%) of the Annual Peak Load of the member's system, plus fifty percent (50%) of the member's Largest Hazard divided by the sum of the similar load and hazard values determined for all members. For a new member with no established Annual Peak Load, the new member's highest projected hourly Load for the next 12 months, as approved by the Operations Committee, will be used in the RRR calculation. For purposes of this computation, the Largest Hazard will be the largest hazard projected for the six month period for which the RRR is being computed. Each member's Annual Peak Load must equal the greater of its Annual Peak Load calculated using the RMRG formula or that member's Largest Hazard.
B-9. MEMBER CONTINGENCY RESERVE QUOTAS: The objective of determining a Contingency Reserve Quota is to ensure that the RMRG is never deficient in Contingency Reserve Capacity including Operating Reserve - Spinning to meet Reportable Disturbances and that all members participate on a proportionate basis meeting the group Contingency Reserve Capacity requirement. Each member is responsible for supplying its Contingency Reserve Quota of Operating Reserve - Spinning and Operating Reserve - Supplemental. When all members' Contingency Reserve Quotas are combined, the sum will equal the Contingency Reserve Capacity unless transmission constraints call for additional reserves. During any period when the transmission system is loaded such that a member's reserves are undeliverable across an Operations Committee Recognized Path, for any Reportable Disturbance, the Administrator will determine, per Operations Committee approved procedures, the allocation of reserves not deliverable from that member to the other members in a manner that will avoid overloading the transmission system as determined by analysis or studies. During these periods when Transmission Path Margin is predicted or otherwise determined to be inadequate, no member's Contingency Reserve Quota will be reduced since the Transmission Path Margin shortfall may become resolved at any time.
B-9.1 The Contingency Reserve Quota for any member is the aggregate Contingency Reserve Capacity required of the members, as defined by Section B-5.1 above, multiplied by the member's Reserve Responsibility Ratio plus
B-9.2 any temporary adjustments caused by transmission limitations under Section B-10 to account for lack of sufficient near term or long term Transmission Path Margin.
B-10. DELIVERY OBLIGATIONS: No transmission reservation will be required to deliver Contingency or Emergency Assistance unless reserves are purchased from non-RMRG members. Transmission reservations will be required for reserves purchased from non-RMRG members. Contingency Reserve costs shall not include any cost associated with transmission service. Continuous monitoring by the Group Administrator in conjunction with seasonal and day-ahead analysis ensures sufficient transmission capacity for RMRG reserve sharing. Incremental transmission useage may occur between pre-defined portions of the RMRG members' combined transmission network, but is effectively limited in real time up to the current System Operating Limit of the transmission path. Members of the RMRG recognize that the mutual benefits associated with the sharing of reserves are significant and thereby agree to waive their rights to financial settlements for any transmission needed by that member to deliver their Contingency Reserve to member systems. Transmission reserved by a member for another member as requested by the other member shall be entitled to payment from the requesting member per the reserving member's transmission tariff or as otherwise mutually allowed.
B-11. PLANNING OF DAILY AND HOURLY RESERVES: The daily planning to provide the Contingency Reserve Capacity required by this Policy B shall be coordinated by the members in accordance with the following practices until such practices are modified by the Operations Committee. B-11.1 By 0900 Mountain Time each day, the Group Administrator shall report to each member the following for each day of the current Planning Window: B-11.1.1 The forecast Group Load for each hour of each day of the current Planning Window; B-11.1.2 the aggregate Contingency Reserve Quota of the Group for each day of the current Planning Window; and, B-11.1.3 The member's Contingency Reserve Quota for each hour of the current Planning Window, determined according to Section B-8. B-11.2 During periods where Group and member Contingency Reserve requirements are not expected to vary as a function of Group Load, the procedure outlined in Section B-11.1 may be curtailed at the discretion of the Group Administrator.
B-11.3 Per the schedule determined by the Operations Committee, the Group Administrator shall evaluate the projected Transmission Path Margin for the following day or day(s) and, if necessary, send out temporary reserve adjustment notifications for member(s) to carry additional Operating Reserves.
B-11.4 In the near term and per Operations Committee approved procedures, should the transmission network exhibit actual Transmission Path Margin shortfall(s) in real time requiring reserve adjustments the Group Administrator shall promptly send out temporary reserve adjustments notifications for the receiving member(s), i.e. those members on the import limited side of the constraint, to carry additional Operating Reserves. When sufficient Transmission Path Margin has been recovered in real time, the Group Administrator shall promptly send out reserve adjustment cancellations. B-11.5 The Operations Committee may establish alternate procedures to address transmission constraints identified in the long term ( 6 months or more in the future ). B-11.6 The Group Administrator shall evaluate the projected Transmission Path Margin for the upcoming season using reserve location, transmission and other information provided by the members. If issues are identified in the seasonal evaluation that project a transmission constraint exceeding a margin approved by the Operations Committee the members will identify the cause of the constraint, whether the issue is due to maintenance and if not how this issue will be corrected prior to the start of the season. If the members are unable to reach agreement on a means to address the constraint, the Contingency Reserve Quota of each member shall be increased by an equivalent percentage of their RRR until such time as the Operations Committee determines an appropriate allocation methodology or until the constraint is alleviated.
B-12. HOURLY MAINTENANCE AND REPORTING OF RESERVES B-12.1 Each member shall maintain Contingency Reserve in the amount established pursuant to B-11. Each member shall also maintain at all times Contingency Reserve - Spinning equal to or greater than fifty percent (50%) of its Contingency Reserve Quota requirement as specified in Section B-9.2. B-12.2 Following each hour, members shall report, or cause to be reported, their Load, their Contingency Reserve Capacity and their Operating Reserve - Spinning to the Group Administrator and to their host Balancing Authority Area B-12.3 Members shall be able to identify the Balancing Authority Area(s) in which their reserves are located and shall make changes immediately known to the Balancing Authority Area(s) affected by the change. B-12.4 A member expecting to be deficient in meeting its quota(s) for future hours should exhaust all efforts to obtain the necessary reserves via the commercial markets. If they are unable to meet their quota(s), the member shall make these deficiencies known to the Group as soon as possible. B-12.5 Should the Contingency Reserves and/or Operating Reserve - Spinning reported pursuant to Sections B-12.2 and/or B-12.4 create an expectation that the Group will be deficient in meeting its aggregate reserve obligations in upcoming hour(s), the Group shall make additional efforts to meet the aggregate reserve obligations of the Group. Non-deficient members shall provide Reserve Assistance by activating and maintaining higher levels of Operating Reserve - Spinning and/or Contingency Reserve than their respective reserve quotas in accordance with the following: B-12.5.1 For a deficiency in Group Operating Reserve - Spinning, members shall make best efforts to commit and start Operating Reserve - Supplemental resources and other generation reserves to increase Group Operating Reserve - Spinning to required levels. For a deficiency in Group Operating Reserve - Supplemental, but not Group Operating Reserve - Spinning, members shall make best efforts to make available other reserves to increase Group Contingency Reserve to required levels. B-12.5.2 The deficiency in Group Contingency Reserve/Operating Reserve - Spinning shall be allocated among the non-deficient members in the manner determined by the Operations Committee which makes maximum use of off-line generating units available to the members. A non-deficient member shall have no obligation to curtail its interruptible load to supply Reserve Assistance. B-12.5.3 A member activating and/or maintaining additional reserves due to the deficiency of another member or members shall be entitled to reimbursement of costs from the deficient member or members as specified in Section B-14.3. Reserve Assistance is provided for the benefit of the Group and not for the specific benefit or credit of a deficient member or members.
B-13. ACTIVATION OF CONTINGENCY RESERVES: The members shall collectively respond as a Group to all Reportable Disturbances. Members shall also respond individually or as a group when requested by another member to provide Contingency Assistance for non-Reportable Disturbances and/or Emergency Assistance. B-13.1 A member, or its agent, experiencing the loss of a resource is responsible for providing notification to the other members by requesting Contingency Assistance. The request for Contingency Assistance is limited to the size of the resource lost. If the resource lost is a generating unit, the request for Contingency Assistance may include the amount of auxiliary loads for the unit that is not lost at the time of the generation trip. B-13.2 Immediately upon receiving notice pursuant to B-13.1, members, in coordination with their respective Balancing Authority Area(s), will proceed to provide Contingency Assistance in an amount reflected in the appropriate Response Matrix plus any temporary adjustments for transmission constraints. Balancing Authority Area operators will coordinate the activation of Contingency Assistance in their respective Balancing Authority Area and coordinate the exchange of Contingency Assistance between Balancing Authority Areas. B-13.3 For Emergencies within the Group, any member that is unable to meet its firm load may request Emergency Assistance from the entire Group via a group response or from any member or members of the Group. A member receiving Contingency Assistance who is unable to meet their firm load following the maximum time period allowed for a Contingency Response may then receive Emergency Assistance, provided that the deficient member meets the following requirements to receive Emergency Assistance and it makes a separate request. B-13.3.1 Concurrent with their request for Emergency Assistance, the requesting member shall activate its remaining available Operating Reserve, including any interruptible load, and shall, as soon as possible, call on its available resources to restore its reserves. B-13.3.2 Upon receiving a request for Emergency Assistance, a member shall respond by activating its Operating Reserves. An individual member's obligation to respond to a request for Emergency Assistance shall be limited to its Reserve Responsibility Ratio multiplied by the amount of Emergency Assistance requested. At its own discretion, a member may choose to supply a larger proportion or all of the requested Emergency Assistance. B-13.3.3 Emergency Assistance shall be scheduled following established emergency scheduling procedures of the Balancing Authority Areas involved. There shall be no explicit 10-minute performance criteria associated with Emergency Assistance. B-13.4 Energy deliveries and receipts for Contingency Assistance and Emergency Assistance shall be made for a period of time as defined below: B-13.4.1 Should the request for Contingency Assistance and or Emergency Assistance commence between minutes ending one (01) to twenty (20) of the clock hour, deliveries and receipts of Contingency Assistance and/or Emergency Assistance shall be made for a minimum period extending until the beginning of the next clock hour up to a maximum period extending an additional sixty (60) minutes to the beginning of the second clock hour after the request was made. For example, a request for assistance made at 1315 would terminate at either 1400 or 1500.
B-13.4.2 Should the request for Contingency Assistance and/or Emergency Assistance commence between minutes ending twenty-one (21) to sixty (00) of the clock hour, deliveries and receipts of Contingency Assistance and/or Emergency Assistance shall be made for a period extending until the beginning of the second clock hour after the request was made. For example, a request for assistance made at 1325 would terminate at 1500. B-13.5 A member receiving Contingency and/or Emergency Assistance is required to resume normal operation using their own reserves and/or make commercial arrangements to meet their load and reserve obligations upon termination of such assistance
B-14. REPORTING AND ACCOUNTING RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE GROUP:
Each member shall report or arrange to be reported their information as required in this Policy. The Operations Committee will adopt a schedule which will govern the timing of data submittals. Any member failing to report their information as required will be subject to the penalties set forth by the Operations Committee. If a member fails to report their information in the time required, the Group Administrator will use the best information available. Routine reporting requirements are specified below. The Group Administrator and/or the Operations Committee may request that certain other reports or data be submitted as needed. B-14.1 Monthly Reporting B-14.1.1 The Operations Committee has the right to require monthly information as needed. B-14.2 Daily and Hourly Reporting B-14.2.1 The short term forecasting for determining the daily reserve quotas will be accomplished under the direction of the Group Administrator. By 0900 Mountain Time each day, the Group Administrator shall report to each member the forecast Group Load, the aggregate Operating Reserve Quotas of the Group, and, the member's hourly Operating Reserve Quota for each day of the current Planning Window as stated in section B-11 of this Policy. B-14.2.2 Each hour, members shall report their actual Load, Contingency Reserve Capacity, and Operating Reserve Spinning to their respective Balancing Authority Area for the preceding hour as stated in section B-12 of this Policy. The Group Administrator will monitor this information to see that the Group reserves are sufficient. B-14.3 Post-Event Reporting B-14.3.1 Members shall maintain sufficient records to be able to demonstrate their performance and the costs they have incurred in response to a Reportable Disturbance and for their supplying of Contingency Assistance. Any data provided for validating performance, shall be from measurement and recording devices which update at an interval no greater than once per minute. B-14.3.2 Within three (3) business days following a response to a Reportable Disturbance, members shall submit performance and cost data to the Group Administrator. Members providing Contingency Assistance shall be entitled to a payment of the greater of thirty dollars per megawatt-hour ($30/MWh) or actual costs plus ten percent (10%). Actual costs for generation may include the incremental costs for fuel, operation and maintenance (O&M) and start-up fuel and expenses. Actual costs for purchased power may include incremental purchased power expenses. Actual costs for curtailing interruptible load may include net loss of revenue and applicable interruption payments to curtailed customers. The Operations Committee shall establish specific reporting requirements for submittals of actual cost claims. B-14.4 Accounting B-14.4.1 For each Reportable Disturbance to which the Group may respond, a Response Matrix will be developed in advance to show each member their responsibility to the Group. The required response of a member shown on the Response Matrix shall generally be in direct proportion to that member's Reserve Responsibility Ratio, subject to modifications by the Operations Committee to improve operational performance of the group. For example, if a member has an RRR of .275, for a Contingency of 300 megawatts, that member will be required to respond with 82.5 megawatts (.275 times 300 megawatts). B-14.4.2 A Receipt Matrix will be developed following each Reportable Disturbance to determine which member(s) incurred a loss of generation resources due to the Contingency and received Contingency Assistance. Members shall be deemed to receive Contingency Assistance in direct proportion to their megawatt share of the Contingency. For example, if a Contingency of 300 megawatts causes member A to lose 200 megawatts and member B to lose 100 megawatts, two-thirds of the Contingency Assistance provided by any member shall be deemed to be received by member A (200/300) and one-third of the Contingency Assistance delivered by any member shall be deemed to be received by member B (100/300). B-14.4.3 Contingency Assistance shall be deemed to be delivered and received according to the Response Matrix and the Receipt Matrix, respectively and as may be modified by the Group Administrator to account for temporary adjustment of reserves due to lack of sufficient Transmission Path Margin. B-14.4.4 The Group Administrator shall account for and notify each member as to their charges and/or credits after each Reportable Disturbance utilizing the information reported pursuant to Section B-14. Each member receiving Contingency Assistance shall pay the same cost per megawatt-hour for such assistance as other members receiving Contingency Assistance for the same Reportable Disturbance. For instances where the obligations to respond are not delivered proportionally to all recipients, costs per megawatt-hour shall be allocated equitably. B-14.4.6 The Group Administrator shall develop accounting procedures which shall demonstrate the performance of the Group in meeting requirements for Reportable Disturbances established by NERC and/or WECC. B-14.4.7 The Group Administrator shall perform a member by member performance audit for each Reportable Disturbance for which the Group fails to meet the required NERC and/or WECC requirement and for the last Reportable Disturbance in any calendar month regardless of overall Group performance. The audits will determine which member(s) failed to meet their obligations pursuant to Section B-13 and the magnitude of their respective deficiency. For the purpose of this requirement a member's individual response shall be deemed to have been requested at such time they are notified to respond to a Reportable Disturbance.
B-15. SETTLEMENTS FOR CONTINGENCY ASSISTANCE, EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE AND RESERVE ASSISTANCE: B-15.1 Members providing Contingency Assistance shall be entitled to recovery of costs as described in Section B-14.3, and shall prepare bills for payment based on information developed by the Group Administrator pursuant to Section B-14.4.4. B-15.2 Members providing Emergency Assistance shall be entitled to a payment of the greater of thirty dollars per megawatt-hour ($30/MWh) or actual costs plus ten percent (10%), provided that the ten percent adder does not exceed ten dollars per megawatt-hour ($10/MWh). Actual costs for generation may include the incremental costs for fuel, operation and maintenance (O&M) and start-up fuel and expenses. Actual costs for purchase power may include incremental purchase power expenses. Actual costs for curtailing interruptible load may include net loss of revenue and applicable interruption payments to curtailed customers. Transmission service costs associated with the delivery of Reserve Assistance shall be accounted for and recovered separately per B-10 above. The billing and payment for Emergency Assistance shall be arranged for between the supplying and receiving members, with the exception that a Group response for Emergency Assistance shall be handled through the Group Administrator in the manner described by Section B-13.3 for Reportable Disturbances . B-15.3 Members providing Reserve Assistance shall be entitled to actual costs plus ten percent (10%) associated with making the reserves available. This could include, but is not limited to, purchasing power, curtailing interruptible load, starting off-line generation including turbines, and/or interrupting schedules. When a member is requested to provide Reserve Assistance, every reasonable effort should be made to provide that assistance. The billing and payment for assistance shall be arranged for between the supplying and receiving members. B-15.4 The Operations Committee shall establish specific reporting requirements for submittals of actual costs claims for Emergency Assistance and Reserve Assistance. B-16. DEFICIENCIES AND PENALTIES: Penalties shall be utilized as a means to encourage continuous compliance of the members with the various obligations outlined within these Policies. Failure to meet said obligations shall constitute a deficiency on the part of the Group and/or individual members. Deficiencies and penalties are solely the responsibility of the Group and its members. No specific performance requirements are expected from nor shall penalties be attributable under these Policies to Balancing Authority Areas, security coordinators, or the Group Administrator for the performance of Balancing Authority Area, or Group Administrator duties. The Operations Committee may abolish obsolete performance penalties and/or establish additional penalties to address performance issues. Any penalty levied may be appealed to and waived by the Operations Committee, by procedures they so establish. The Operations Committee may designate fixed periods, during which one or more of the prescribed performance penalties may be temporarily reduced and/or made inapplicable. B-16.1 For deficiencies of the Group in meeting the NERC and/or WECC requirements for Reportable Disturbances which cannot be specifically attributable to deficient performance of an individual member or members, the responsibility of the Group to carry additional Operating Reserve Capacity and/or pay monetary penalties shall be shared by the Group in proportion to each member's Reserve Responsibility Ratio. B-16.2 For deficiencies of the Group in meeting the NERC and/or WECC requirements for carrying Operating Reserves and/or for Reportable Disturbances which can be specifically attributable to deficient performance of an individual member or members, the responsibility of the Group to carry additional Operating Reserve Capacity shall be met by the deficient member or members carrying additional Operating Reserve Capacity in proportion to their respective deficiency. In addition, the responsibility of the Group to pay monetary penalties specifically attributable to deficient performance of an individual member or members shall be met by the deficient member or members making such payments in proportion to their respective deficiency. For the purpose of this Section B-16.2, all Reportable Disturbances reviewed pursuant to Section B-14.4.7 shall be utilized to determine a member's performance. B-16.3 For deficiencies by a member in reported Operating Reserve Capacity or Operating Reserve - Spinning capacity for an hour pursuant to Section B-9 the penalty shall be $100 per megawatt for each megawatt the member falls short of meeting the requirement. B-16.4 For deficiencies by a member in failing to respond to a Reportable Disturbance with the required Operating Reserve within the required ten (10) minute period, the penalty will be $100 per megawatt for each megawatt the member fell short of their requirement. B-16.5 For deficiencies by a member in failing to properly report monthly data pursuant to Section B-14.1, the penalty shall be one thousand dollars ($1000) per day for each day the information required goes unreported past the due date. B-16.6 For deficiencies by a member in failing to report any single hour's data pursuant to Section B-14.2, the penalty shall be one hundred dollars ($100) per hour the information required goes unreported ( up to $1000 per day ) subject to adjustment by the Operations Committee. B-16.7 For deficiencies by a member in failing to report Reportable Disturbance information pursuant to Section B-14.3.2, the penalty shall be one thousand dollars ($1000) for each day the required information goes unreported past the due date.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP POLICY D COMMUNICATIONS, HARDWARE, SOFTWARE
D-1 Reserved for future use.
D-2 PURPOSE: The purpose of this Policy is to define the communication methods for: 1) sending and receiving the required operational and accounting data for normal and routine operation, and 2) activating reserves when required. Hardware and software requirements for operation and accounting are conceptually defined along with associated distribution of costs to members.
D-3 TERM: This Policy shall continue in effect unless and until amended or superseded in accordance with the bylaws.
D-4 COMMUNICATIONS USED FOR DATA REPORTING: The Group Administrator will report the Planning Window requirements to each member by 0900 Mountain Time each day as required by Policy B. This communication will be via fax or other electronic medium. In real-time, before twenty (20) minutes past the top of every hour of every day, each member will report their actual Load, Operating Reserve Capacity, and Operating Reserve - Spinning capacity as required by Policy B. Communication of this hourly data will be to the member's designated Balancing Authority Area. The preferred communication method is by voice, although the Inter-Utility Data Group System (IUDG) or other suitably reliable method may be utilized. Voice communications data shall be verified at least once each day. The member's hourly data gathered by the Balancing Authority Areas will be combined and made available to the Group. Specific procedures will be developed by the Operations Committee. Initially the IUDG will be used for this communication with voice as a backup.
D-5 COMMUNICATIONS USED TO ACTIVATE RESERVES: The Rocky Mountain Reserve Group Automated Reserve Sharing (ARS) system will be the primary communication method used to request Contingency and/or Emergency Assistance. The Rocky Mountain Reserve Group hotline will be the preferred backup communication system to the ARS. Suitable procedures will be developed and implemented by the Operations Committee to make communications as direct and efficient as possible. Members that do not have access to the hotline are required to make other arrangements to relay communications. D-6 HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE: D-6.1 Hourly Data Communication and computer hardware and software will be required for the Group's accounting and operating procedures. This equipment/software will be utilized to access the hourly data input from the Balancing Authority Areas into the IUDG for accounting and operational purposes, and will input hourly data back into the IUDG for access by members who so desire. D-6.2 Real-Time Data Communication and computer hardware and software will be required to provide real-time data to the Balancing Authority Areas, to members who so desire, and to the Rocky Mountain Reliability Coordinator if desirable. An example of this type of data is the Group area control error (A.C.E.) signal.
D-7 RESPONSIBILITY OF COST AND COST DISTRIBUTIONS FOR COMMUNICATIONS,HARDWARE, AND SOFTWARE: All costs related to voice circuits, to the hotline, and to access to the IUDG will be borne by the individual member. Communication channels, equipment, hardware, and software required to allow the Group Administrator to effectively operate, monitor, and account for all required activities will be a Group cost and will be treated as an assessment as described in the bylaws. Communication channels, equipment, hardware, and software required to allow the Balancing Authority Areas to monitor/review necessary real-time data will be a Group cost and will be treated as described in the bylaws. Entities other than Balancing Authority Areas, who desire real-time data will be responsible for all associated costs.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESERVE GROUP POLICY E
GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE POLICIES
E-1 Reserved for future use.
E-2 PURPOSE: The purpose of this Policy is to define general administrative policies of the RMRG.
E-3 TERM: This Policy shall continue in effect unless and until amended or superseded in accordance with the bylaws.
E-4 DISPUTE RESOLUTION: If any controversy, dispute or claim arising out of or relating to the interpretation of RMRG Bylaws or Policies, or the alleged breach hereof between or among members, cannot be resolved within ninety (90) days after its initial identification, the aggrieved member or members may call for arbitration. If the members involved consent to arbitration, such arbitration shall be conducted in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association and as provided in the Federal Arbitration Act, 9 US C.LL 1-16 The members agree to accept the Arbitrator's award as final and binding upon them, except as provided in the Federal Arbitration Acts. In the event that all members involved do not consent to arbitration, the aggrieved member or members shall be free to seek resolution of the controversy, dispute or claim in such manner as may be provided by law.
E-5 AUDIT PROVISIONS: Members shall maintain accurate records and books of account in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and consistent with the RMRG Bylaws and Policies. Said books and records shall present fairly all costs and expenses utilized either directly or indirectly in computing any changes or payments to or from other members for RMRG purposes.
Upon thirty (30) days written notice, a member shall afford any other member reasonable access to relevant records and books of account required to substantiate calculations of costs for Contingency Assistance, Emergency Assistance, and/ or Reserve Assistance provided within the RMRG. Members shall have access to the other member's records for these purposes for a period of twelve (12) months following the date of the receipt of the billing containing the charges or costs in question.
The twelve (12) month audit period shall survive beyond the effective period of the RMRG, if necessary to meet the audit opportunity requirements stated above.
E-6 BOARD AND COMMITTEE VOTING SEQUENCE:
A quorum for any meeting of the board shall be the presence of two-thirds of the full member representatives having, in aggregate, two-thirds of the member voting strength. The act of a two-thirds double majority of the directors present shall be an act of the directors, meaning that the issue must be approved by two-thirds of the directors present and must be approved by two-thirds of the voting strength represented. Results of the first vote will be tallied based on two-thirds of the voting strength represented. If the issue passes the first vote it will then move to the final vote where it must be approved by a two-thirds majority of the members present based on one member one vote. This section also applies to all Committees including the Operations Committee.
By-Laws & Policies Major Revision-FERC accepted to be effective on April 1, 2013. Real time operation - Added new Section 9.in Article 2, Board approved on April 30, 2019
